title: Disease Assessment & Integration | Diastology in atrial fibrillation [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL statements that are true based on the scenario:
AF rhythm. Averaged over 5 beats: E 90 cm/s, septal e' 4 cm/s, lateral e' 5 cm/s, TRV 3.6 m/s, LAVI 40 mL/m².
Best statement?

Rationale: In AF, use averaged beats and integrated markers (E/e', TRV, LA volume). Avoid single-parameter
conclusions and document uncertainty when needed.
Pearls: Average beats with similar RR intervals.  When uncertain, say 'indeterminate' rather than guessing. 
Multi-select rewards integrated thinking; avoid single-parameter shortcuts.
opts: LA size is irrelevant in AF
Diastolic function cannot be assessed in AF, so no statement should be made
Only mitral E velocity is needed to diagnose elevated filling pressure
Elevated LV filling pressures are likely (integrated AF approach); average multiple beats and report limitations
Document limitations, reconcile discordance, and consider adjunct testing if uncertainty persists
raw:
1. ACS2-0001 — Disease Assessment & Integration | Diastology in atrial fibrillation [Select all that apply]
Select ALL statements that are true based on the scenario:
AF rhythm. Averaged over 5 beats: E 90 cm/s, septal e' 4 cm/s, lateral e' 5 cm/s, TRV 3.6 m/s, LAVI 40 mL/m².
Best statement?

A. LA size is irrelevant in AF

B. Diastolic function cannot be assessed in AF, so no statement should be made

C. Only mitral E velocity is needed to diagnose elevated filling pressure

D. Elevated LV filling pressures are likely (integrated AF approach); average multiple beats and report
limitations

E. Document limitations, reconcile discordance, and consider adjunct testing if uncertainty persists
Correct: D, E
Rationale: In AF, use averaged beats and integrated markers (E/e', TRV, LA volume). Avoid single-parameter
conclusions and document uncertainty when needed.
Pearls: Average beats with similar RR intervals.  When uncertain, say 'indeterminate' rather than guessing. 
Multi-select rewards integrated thinking; avoid single-parameter shortcuts.

title: Disease Assessment & Integration | Constrictive vs restrictive physiology [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL statements that are true based on the scenario:
Echo features:
- Mitral inflow respiratory E-wave variation: 28%
- Hepatic vein flow: expiratory diastolic reversal
- Septal bounce: present
- Medial e' (cm/s): 13
Best interpretation?

Rationale: Exaggerated respiratory inflow variation + septal bounce + hepatic vein expiratory reversal supports
constriction; medial e' often preserved/augmented.
Pearls: Use a pattern of findings; any single parameter can mislead.  Correlate with pericardial history and
cross-sectional imaging.  Multi-select rewards integrated thinking; avoid single-parameter shortcuts.
opts: Severe tricuspid regurgitation alone explains all findings
Echo can never differentiate these entities
Constrictive pericarditis physiology is more likely
Document limitations, reconcile discordance, and consider adjunct testing if uncertainty persists
raw:

title: Disease Assessment & Integration | Constrictive vs restrictive physiology [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL statements that are true based on the scenario:
Echo features:
- Mitral inflow respiratory E-wave variation: 8%
- Hepatic vein flow: minimal reversal
- Septal bounce: absent
- Medial e' (cm/s): 6
Best interpretation?

Rationale: Restriction shows high filling pressures with limited respiratory variation and reduced e'; septal bounce is
typically absent.
Pearls: Use a pattern of findings; any single parameter can mislead.  Correlate with pericardial history and
cross-sectional imaging.  Multi-select rewards integrated thinking; avoid single-parameter shortcuts.
opts: Restrictive cardiomyopathy physiology is more likely
Severe tricuspid regurgitation alone explains all findings
Echo can never differentiate these entities
Document limitations, reconcile discordance, and consider adjunct testing if uncertainty persists

title: Disease Assessment & Integration | Constrictive vs restrictive physiology [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL statements that are true based on the scenario:
Echo features:
- Mitral inflow respiratory E-wave variation: 32%
- Hepatic vein flow: expiratory diastolic reversal
- Septal bounce: present
- Medial e' (cm/s): 13
Best interpretation?

Rationale: Exaggerated respiratory inflow variation + septal bounce + hepatic vein expiratory reversal supports
constriction; medial e' often preserved/augmented.
Pearls: Use a pattern of findings; any single parameter can mislead.  Correlate with pericardial history and
cross-sectional imaging.  Multi-select rewards integrated thinking; avoid single-parameter shortcuts.
opts: Severe tricuspid regurgitation alone explains all findings
Echo can never differentiate these entities
Constrictive pericarditis physiology is more likely
Document limitations, reconcile discordance, and consider adjunct testing if uncertainty persists

AF rhythm. Averaged over 5 beats: E 110 cm/s, septal e' 6 cm/s, lateral e' 8 cm/s, TRV 3.2 m/s, LAVI 40 mL/m².
Best statement?

A. Diastolic function cannot be assessed in AF, so no statement should be made

B. Only mitral E velocity is needed to diagnose elevated filling pressure

C. LA size is irrelevant in AF

D. Elevated LV filling pressures are likely (integrated AF approach); average multiple beats and report
limitations
Correct: D
Rationale: In AF, use averaged beats and integrated markers (E/e', TRV, LA volume). Avoid single-parameter
conclusions and document uncertainty when needed.

Pearls: Average beats with similar RR intervals.  When uncertain, say 'indeterminate' rather than guessing.

title: Disease Assessment & Integration | Constrictive vs restrictive physiology
stem:
Echo features:
- Mitral inflow respiratory E-wave variation: 40%
- Hepatic vein flow: expiratory diastolic reversal
- Septal bounce: present
- Medial e' (cm/s): 9
Best interpretation?

Rationale: Exaggerated respiratory inflow variation + septal bounce + hepatic vein expiratory reversal supports
constriction; medial e' often preserved/augmented.
Pearls: Use a pattern of findings; any single parameter can mislead.  Correlate with pericardial history and
cross-sectional imaging.
opts: Echo can never differentiate these entities
Constrictive pericarditis physiology is more likely
Severe tricuspid regurgitation alone explains all findings
raw:

title: Disease Assessment & Integration | Constrictive vs restrictive physiology
stem:
Echo features:
- Mitral inflow respiratory E-wave variation: 8%
- Hepatic vein flow: minimal reversal
- Septal bounce: absent
- Medial e' (cm/s): 6
Best interpretation?

Rationale: Restriction shows high filling pressures with limited respiratory variation and reduced e'; septal bounce is
typically absent.
Pearls: Use a pattern of findings; any single parameter can mislead.  Correlate with pericardial history and
cross-sectional imaging.
opts: Echo can never differentiate these entities
Restrictive cardiomyopathy physiology is more likely
Severe tricuspid regurgitation alone explains all findings

title: Right Heart | Pulmonary hypertension probability
stem:
A patient has TR peak velocity 3.2 m/s. Additional signs:
RV enlargement: no, septal flattening: no, PA dilation: no, IVC plethoric: yes
What is the best echo-based PH probability statement?

Rationale: TRV plus supportive signs determine echo-based PH probability; report probability and limitations, and
integrate with clinical context.
Pearls: Report probability, not certainty.  Supportive signs matter when TRV is borderline or limited.
opts: Intermediate probability of pulmonary hypertension (echo probability)
TR velocity alone is sufficient; supportive signs never matter
PH severity can be graded accurately on echo without invasive confirmation in all cases
PH is excluded because TR velocity is not perfectly measurable

title: Right Heart | Acute RV strain / PE physiology
stem:
A patient with sudden hypoxia has echo: TAPSE 1.5 cm, RV free-wall strain -15%, TRV 3.2 m/s, McConnell sign:
absent.
Best interpretation?

Rationale: Acute PE can cause RV dysfunction: reduced TAPSE and less negative RV strain; no single sign is
definitive—use an integrated pattern.
Pearls: Avoid over-calling based on one sign.  Document RV size, function, TRV, and septal configuration.
opts: This pattern is diagnostic of chronic PH only
RV strain values cannot be used clinically
Echo does not strongly support severe acute RV strain; integrate with clinical probability and imaging
Normal RV function is confirmed regardless of TAPSE
raw:

A patient with sudden hypoxia has echo: TAPSE 1.2 cm, RV free-wall strain -15%, TRV 2.8 m/s, McConnell sign:
present.
Best interpretation?

A. This pattern is diagnostic of chronic PH only

B. Normal RV function is confirmed regardless of TAPSE

C. Echo does not strongly support severe acute RV strain; integrate with clinical probability and imaging

D. RV strain values cannot be used clinically
Correct: C
Rationale: Acute PE can cause RV dysfunction: reduced TAPSE and less negative RV strain; no single sign is
definitive—use an integrated pattern.
Pearls: Avoid over-calling based on one sign.  Document RV size, function, TRV, and septal configuration.

title: Right Heart | Pulmonary hypertension probability
stem:
A patient has TR peak velocity 3.6 m/s. Additional signs:
RV enlargement: no, septal flattening: no, PA dilation: yes, IVC plethoric: no
What is the best echo-based PH probability statement?

Rationale: TRV plus supportive signs determine echo-based PH probability; report probability and limitations, and
integrate with clinical context.
Pearls: Report probability, not certainty.  Supportive signs matter when TRV is borderline or limited.
opts: TR velocity alone is sufficient; supportive signs never matter
High probability of pulmonary hypertension (echo probability)
PH severity can be graded accurately on echo without invasive confirmation in all cases
PH is excluded because TR velocity is not perfectly measurable

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Aortic stenosis (continuity equation)
stem:
A 74-year-old with exertional dyspnea has Doppler data:
LVOT diameter 2.0 cm, LVOT VTI 18.1 cm, AV VTI 64.1 cm.
Assuming accurate measurements and circular LVOT, what is the calculated AVA?

Rationale: AVA = (CSA_LVOT × VTI_LVOT) / VTI_AV. CSA = π(d/2)² = π(2.0/2)² ≈ 3.14 cm². AVA ≈ 0.89 cm².
Pearls: Most continuity errors come from LVOT diameter measurement and unit mix-ups.  Sanity-check AVA
against DVI and velocity/gradient trends.

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Mitral regurgitation integration
stem:
A 63-year-old with fatigue has MR quantification:
EROA 0.2 cm², regurgitant volume 60 mL, LAVI 40 mL/m².
Pulmonary venous systolic reversal: present. Flail leaflet morphology: absent.
What is the best integrative interpretation?

Rationale: MR grading is integrative: quantify (EROA/RVol) and support with consequences (LA/LV remodeling,
pulmonary venous flow) and morphology (flail).
Pearls: Eccentric jets: rely more on quantitative markers and consequences than jet area.  Mechanism (primary vs
secondary) should be stated clearly.
opts: At least moderate-to-severe MR; reconcile quantitative and supportive findings and define mechanism (TEE/3D)
Quantification is invalid if any arrhythmia is present, so ignore it
Mild MR; no need for further characterization
Severity cannot be determined by echo; only cath can grade MR
raw:

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Discordant aortic stenosis
stem:
A 78-year-old with exertional dyspnea and BP 160/90 has:
EF 55%, AVA 0.75 cm², mean gradient 20 mmHg, Vmax 3.1 m/s, SVI 26 mL/m².
Which interpretation/next step best fits an ACS-level approach?

Rationale: AVA < 1.0 cm² suggests severe range, but gradients are low. With preserved EF and SVI < 35 mL/m²,
paradoxical low-flow physiology can explain discordance. Next steps are to verify LVOT/VTIs and consider adjunct
confirmation in context.
Pearls: Low flow can exist with preserved EF due to concentric remodeling and small LV cavity.  Treat significant
hypertension during the exam and reassess when possible.
opts: Paradoxical low-flow, low-gradient severe AS is likely; verify measurements and consider adjunct confirmation (e.g., CT calcium scoring or stress echo depending on context)
Severe high-gradient AS; proceed without reconciling discordance
Moderate AS; no further evaluation is needed if symptomatic
Normal valve hemodynamics; symptoms are non-cardiac
raw:
134. ACS2-0134 — Valvular Heart Disease | Discordant aortic stenosis
A 78-year-old with exertional dyspnea and BP 160/90 has:
EF 55%, AVA 0.75 cm², mean gradient 20 mmHg, Vmax 3.1 m/s, SVI 26 mL/m².
Which interpretation/next step best fits an ACS-level approach?

A. Paradoxical low-flow, low-gradient severe AS is likely; verify measurements and consider adjunct
confirmation (e.g., CT calcium scoring or stress echo depending on context)

B. Severe high-gradient AS; proceed without reconciling discordance

C. Moderate AS; no further evaluation is needed if symptomatic

D. Normal valve hemodynamics; symptoms are non-cardiac
Correct: A
Rationale: AVA < 1.0 cm² suggests severe range, but gradients are low. With preserved EF and SVI < 35 mL/m²,
paradoxical low-flow physiology can explain discordance. Next steps are to verify LVOT/VTIs and consider adjunct
confirmation in context.
Pearls: Low flow can exist with preserved EF due to concentric remodeling and small LV cavity.  Treat significant
hypertension during the exam and reassess when possible.

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Endocarditis and complications [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL findings that strongly support infective endocarditis or its complications on echo:

Rationale: Vegetations, prosthetic dehiscence, new paravalvular regurgitation, and periannular abscess are strong
supportive findings; Lambl excrescences are benign mimics.
Pearls: TEE is more sensitive for prosthetic valves and abscess.  Compare to prior studies whenever possible.
opts: New prosthetic valve dehiscence or rocking motion
Mobile echodensity on the upstream side of a valve consistent with vegetation (with appropriate clinical context)
Small, stable Lambl excrescence unchanged from prior study
New paravalvular regurgitation around a prosthetic valve
Periannular abscess suggested by echo-free space or thickened periannular tissue
raw:

stem:
A 74-year-old with exertional dyspnea has Doppler data:
LVOT diameter 2.0 cm, LVOT VTI 18.7 cm, AV VTI 81.1 cm.
Assuming accurate measurements and circular LVOT, what is the calculated AVA?

Rationale: AVA = (CSA_LVOT × VTI_LVOT) / VTI_AV. CSA = π(d/2)² = π(2.0/2)² ≈ 3.14 cm². AVA ≈ 0.72 cm².
Pearls: Most continuity errors come from LVOT diameter measurement and unit mix-ups.  Sanity-check AVA
against DVI and velocity/gradient trends.
raw:
137. ACS2-0137 — Valvular Heart Disease | Aortic stenosis (continuity equation)
A 74-year-old with exertional dyspnea has Doppler data:
LVOT diameter 2.0 cm, LVOT VTI 18.7 cm, AV VTI 81.1 cm.
Assuming accurate measurements and circular LVOT, what is the calculated AVA?


A. AVA ≈ 0.18 cm²

B. AVA ≈ 0.96 cm²

C. AVA ≈ 0.72 cm² (continuity equation)

D. AVA ≈ 13.62 cm²
Correct: C
Rationale: AVA = (CSA_LVOT × VTI_LVOT) / VTI_AV. CSA = π(d/2)² = π(2.0/2)² ≈ 3.14 cm². AVA ≈ 0.72 cm².
Pearls: Most continuity errors come from LVOT diameter measurement and unit mix-ups.  Sanity-check AVA
against DVI and velocity/gradient trends.

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Discordant aortic stenosis
stem:
A 78-year-old with exertional dyspnea and BP 160/90 has:
EF 55%, AVA 0.75 cm², mean gradient 24 mmHg, Vmax 3.4 m/s, SVI 28 mL/m².
Which interpretation/next step best fits an ACS-level approach?

Rationale: AVA < 1.0 cm² suggests severe range, but gradients are low. With preserved EF and SVI < 35 mL/m²,
paradoxical low-flow physiology can explain discordance. Next steps are to verify LVOT/VTIs and consider adjunct
confirmation in context.
Pearls: Low flow can exist with preserved EF due to concentric remodeling and small LV cavity.  Treat significant
hypertension during the exam and reassess when possible.
opts: Severe high-gradient AS; proceed without reconciling discordance
Moderate AS; no further evaluation is needed if symptomatic
Normal valve hemodynamics; symptoms are non-cardiac
Paradoxical low-flow, low-gradient severe AS is likely; verify measurements and consider adjunct confirmation (e.g., CT calcium scoring or stress echo depending on context)
raw:

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Endocarditis and complications [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL findings that strongly support infective endocarditis or its complications on echo:

Rationale: Vegetations, prosthetic dehiscence, new paravalvular regurgitation, and periannular abscess are strong
supportive findings; Lambl excrescences are benign mimics.
Pearls: TEE is more sensitive for prosthetic valves and abscess.  Compare to prior studies whenever possible.
opts: New prosthetic valve dehiscence or rocking motion
Mobile echodensity on the upstream side of a valve consistent with vegetation (with appropriate clinical context)
Small, stable Lambl excrescence unchanged from prior study
New paravalvular regurgitation around a prosthetic valve
Periannular abscess suggested by echo-free space or thickened periannular tissue
raw:
139. ACS2-0139 — Valvular Heart Disease | Endocarditis and complications [Select all that apply]
Select ALL findings that strongly support infective endocarditis or its complications on echo:

A. New prosthetic valve dehiscence or rocking motion

B. Mobile echodensity on the upstream side of a valve consistent with vegetation (with appropriate clinical
context)

C. Small, stable Lambl excrescence unchanged from prior study

D. New paravalvular regurgitation around a prosthetic valve

E. Periannular abscess suggested by echo-free space or thickened periannular tissue
Correct: A, B, D, E
Rationale: Vegetations, prosthetic dehiscence, new paravalvular regurgitation, and periannular abscess are strong
supportive findings; Lambl excrescences are benign mimics.
Pearls: TEE is more sensitive for prosthetic valves and abscess.  Compare to prior studies whenever possible.

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Mitral regurgitation integration
stem:
A 63-year-old with fatigue has MR quantification:
EROA 0.2 cm², regurgitant volume 75 mL, LAVI 40 mL/m².
Pulmonary venous systolic reversal: absent. Flail leaflet morphology: present.
What is the best integrative interpretation?

Rationale: MR grading is integrative: quantify (EROA/RVol) and support with consequences (LA/LV remodeling,
pulmonary venous flow) and morphology (flail).
Pearls: Eccentric jets: rely more on quantitative markers and consequences than jet area.  Mechanism (primary vs
secondary) should be stated clearly.
opts: Severity cannot be determined by echo; only cath can grade MR
Mild MR; no need for further characterization
At least moderate-to-severe MR; reconcile quantitative and supportive findings and define mechanism (TEE/3D)
Quantification is invalid if any arrhythmia is present, so ignore it
raw:

153. ACS2-0153 — Valvular Heart Disease | Discordant aortic stenosis
A 78-year-old with exertional dyspnea and BP 170/95 has:
EF 60%, AVA 0.95 cm², mean gradient 32 mmHg, Vmax 3.6 m/s, SVI 24 mL/m².
Which interpretation/next step best fits an ACS-level approach?

A. Severe high-gradient AS; proceed without reconciling discordance

B. Paradoxical low-flow, low-gradient severe AS is likely; verify measurements and consider adjunct
confirmation (e.g., CT calcium scoring or stress echo depending on context)


C. Normal valve hemodynamics; symptoms are non-cardiac

D. Moderate AS; no further evaluation is needed if symptomatic
Correct: B
Rationale: AVA < 1.0 cm² suggests severe range, but gradients are low. With preserved EF and SVI < 35 mL/m²,
paradoxical low-flow physiology can explain discordance. Next steps are to verify LVOT/VTIs and consider adjunct
confirmation in context.
Pearls: Low flow can exist with preserved EF due to concentric remodeling and small LV cavity.  Treat significant
hypertension during the exam and reassess when possible.

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Aortic stenosis (continuity equation)
stem:
A 74-year-old with exertional dyspnea has Doppler data:
LVOT diameter 2.1 cm, LVOT VTI 14.8 cm, AV VTI 90.8 cm.
Assuming accurate measurements and circular LVOT, what is the calculated AVA?

Rationale: AVA = (CSA_LVOT × VTI_LVOT) / VTI_AV. CSA = π(d/2)² = π(2.1/2)² ≈ 3.46 cm². AVA ≈ 0.56 cm².
Pearls: Most continuity errors come from LVOT diameter measurement and unit mix-ups.  Sanity-check AVA
against DVI and velocity/gradient trends.
raw:
161. ACS2-0161 — Valvular Heart Disease | Aortic stenosis (continuity equation)
A 74-year-old with exertional dyspnea has Doppler data:
LVOT diameter 2.1 cm, LVOT VTI 14.8 cm, AV VTI 90.8 cm.
Assuming accurate measurements and circular LVOT, what is the calculated AVA?

A. AVA ≈ 0.79 cm²

B. AVA ≈ 0.14 cm²

C. AVA ≈ 21.25 cm²


D. AVA ≈ 0.56 cm² (continuity equation)
Correct: D
Rationale: AVA = (CSA_LVOT × VTI_LVOT) / VTI_AV. CSA = π(d/2)² = π(2.1/2)² ≈ 3.46 cm². AVA ≈ 0.56 cm².
Pearls: Most continuity errors come from LVOT diameter measurement and unit mix-ups.  Sanity-check AVA
against DVI and velocity/gradient trends.

confirmation (e.g., CT calcium scoring or stress echo depending on context)

C. Severe high-gradient AS; proceed without reconciling discordance

D. Normal valve hemodynamics; symptoms are non-cardiac
Correct: B
Rationale: AVA < 1.0 cm² suggests severe range, but gradients are low. With preserved EF and SVI < 35 mL/m²,
paradoxical low-flow physiology can explain discordance. Next steps are to verify LVOT/VTIs and consider adjunct
confirmation in context.
Pearls: Low flow can exist with preserved EF due to concentric remodeling and small LV cavity.  Treat significant
hypertension during the exam and reassess when possible.

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Endocarditis and complications [Select all that apply]
stem:
Select ALL findings that strongly support infective endocarditis or its complications on echo:

Rationale: Vegetations, prosthetic dehiscence, new paravalvular regurgitation, and periannular abscess are strong
supportive findings; Lambl excrescences are benign mimics.
Pearls: TEE is more sensitive for prosthetic valves and abscess.  Compare to prior studies whenever possible.
opts: New prosthetic valve dehiscence or rocking motion
Mobile echodensity on the upstream side of a valve consistent with vegetation (with appropriate clinical context)
Small, stable Lambl excrescence unchanged from prior study
New paravalvular regurgitation around a prosthetic valve
Periannular abscess suggested by echo-free space or thickened periannular tissue

title: Valvular Heart Disease | Aortic stenosis (continuity equation)
stem:
A 74-year-old with exertional dyspnea has Doppler data:
LVOT diameter 1.8 cm, LVOT VTI 20.7 cm, AV VTI 82.0 cm.
Assuming accurate measurements and circular LVOT, what is the calculated AVA?

Rationale: AVA = (CSA_LVOT × VTI_LVOT) / VTI_AV. CSA = π(d/2)² = π(1.8/2)² ≈ 2.54 cm². AVA ≈ 0.64 cm².
Pearls: Most continuity errors come from LVOT diameter measurement and unit mix-ups.  Sanity-check AVA
against DVI and velocity/gradient trends.
raw:

title: Structural / Interventional Imaging | MitraClip post-procedure assessment
stem:
After MitraClip for secondary (functional) MR, immediate post-TEE shows:
3D MVA 4.0 cm², mean gradient 5 mmHg, residual MR ~3+.
What is the most appropriate reporting priority?

Rationale: Post-clip assessment requires balancing MR reduction and stenosis risk; gradients are flow-dependent
and should be interpreted with HR/CO and MVA.
Pearls: Always report HR/flow state when quoting gradients.  Avoid PHT-based MVA immediately
post-intervention.
opts: Any mean gradient ≥4 mmHg proves clip failure and requires removal
Residual MR cannot be assessed after clip procedures
Transmitral gradients are irrelevant after MitraClip; grade MR only by jet area
Integrate residual MR grade, transmitral gradient, leaflet grasp, and flow state; avoid iatrogenic MS while optimizing MR reduction
raw:

3D MVA 4.0 cm², mean gradient 6 mmHg, residual MR ~1+.
What is the most appropriate reporting priority?

A. Any mean gradient ≥4 mmHg proves clip failure and requires removal

B. Transmitral gradients are irrelevant after MitraClip; grade MR only by jet area

C. Residual MR cannot be assessed after clip procedures

D. Integrate residual MR grade, transmitral gradient, leaflet grasp, and flow state; avoid iatrogenic MS while
optimizing MR reduction
Correct: D
Rationale: Post-clip assessment requires balancing MR reduction and stenosis risk; gradients are flow-dependent
and should be interpreted with HR/CO and MVA.
Pearls: Always report HR/flow state when quoting gradients.  Avoid PHT-based MVA immediately
post-intervention.

title: Advanced Imaging | Contrast echo (LV thrombus)
stem:
Post-anterior MI (EF 25%). Apical endocardial definition is poor. Best next step to evaluate LV thrombus?

Rationale: Contrast improves LV cavity opacification and increases sensitivity for mural thrombus, especially in low
EF/anterior MI.
Pearls: State image-quality limitations if contrast is not used.  Thrombus detection is a high-impact indication for
contrast.
opts: Do not use contrast; thrombus is excluded if apical views are difficult
Use ultrasound contrast to improve endocardial definition and assess for LV thrombus in a high-risk setting
Defer imaging; echo cannot evaluate thrombus
Rely on color Doppler to detect thrombus
raw:

title: Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
stem:
Which TEE view is most appropriate to evaluate: interatrial septum?

Rationale: Bicaval best shows IAS and rim assessment.
Pearls: TEE is a sweep, not a snapshot.  Document multiplane range and limitations.
raw:
233. ACS2-0233 — Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
Which TEE view is most appropriate to evaluate: interatrial septum?

A. Mid-esophageal bicaval view ~90–110°

B. Descending aorta short-axis view

C. Upper esophageal aortic arch view


D. Deep transgastric long-axis ~0–20°
Correct: A
Rationale: Bicaval best shows IAS and rim assessment.
Pearls: TEE is a sweep, not a snapshot.  Document multiplane range and limitations.

title: Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
stem:

Rationale: Pulmonary vein Doppler is assessed by careful probe rotation and multiplane sweeps.

opts: Mid-esophageal views with PV Doppler sweep (rotate from 4-chamber / 2-chamber)

Post-anterior MI (EF 40%). Apical endocardial definition is poor. Best next step to evaluate LV thrombus?

Rationale: Contrast improves LV cavity opacification and increases sensitivity for mural thrombus, especially in low
EF/anterior MI.
Pearls: State image-quality limitations if contrast is not used.  Thrombus detection is a high-impact indication for
contrast.
opts: Use ultrasound contrast to improve endocardial definition and assess for LV thrombus in a high-risk setting
Defer imaging; echo cannot evaluate thrombus
Rely on color Doppler to detect thrombus
Do not use contrast; thrombus is excluded if apical views are difficult
raw:
244. ACS2-0244 — Advanced Imaging | Contrast echo (LV thrombus)
Post-anterior MI (EF 40%). Apical endocardial definition is poor. Best next step to evaluate LV thrombus?

A. Use ultrasound contrast to improve endocardial definition and assess for LV thrombus in a high-risk setting

B. Defer imaging; echo cannot evaluate thrombus

C. Rely on color Doppler to detect thrombus

D. Do not use contrast; thrombus is excluded if apical views are difficult
Correct: A
Rationale: Contrast improves LV cavity opacification and increases sensitivity for mural thrombus, especially in low
EF/anterior MI.
Pearls: State image-quality limitations if contrast is not used.  Thrombus detection is a high-impact indication for
contrast.

title: Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
stem:
Which TEE view is most appropriate to evaluate: LAA?

Rationale: ME 2-chamber is commonly used for LAA evaluation with angle sweeps.
Pearls: TEE is a sweep, not a snapshot.  Document multiplane range and limitations.
raw:
246. ACS2-0246 — Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
Which TEE view is most appropriate to evaluate: LAA?

A. Upper esophageal aortic arch view

B. Mid-esophageal 2-chamber ~80–110° with LAA-focused sweep

C. Deep transgastric long-axis ~0–20°

D. Descending aorta short-axis view
Correct: B
Rationale: ME 2-chamber is commonly used for LAA evaluation with angle sweeps.
Pearls: TEE is a sweep, not a snapshot.  Document multiplane range and limitations.

title: Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
stem:
Which TEE view is most appropriate to evaluate: pulmonary veins?

Rationale: Pulmonary vein Doppler is assessed by careful probe rotation and multiplane sweeps.
Pearls: TEE is a sweep, not a snapshot.  Document multiplane range and limitations.
opts: Mid-esophageal views with PV Doppler sweep (rotate from 4-chamber / 2-chamber)
raw:
247. ACS2-0247 — Advanced Imaging | TEE view selection
Which TEE view is most appropriate to evaluate: pulmonary veins?

A. Descending aorta short-axis view

B. Upper esophageal aortic arch view

C. Deep transgastric long-axis ~0–20°


Correct: D

title: Clinical Integration | Managing discordance and uncertainty
stem:
A symptomatic patient has borderline or discordant echo findings that could change management. Which next step
is most appropriate to reduce diagnostic uncertainty while remaining guideline-aligned?

Rationale: ACS-level reporting integrates multiple parameters, improves data quality, and escalates appropriately
when uncertainty persists.
Pearls: Good reports guide next actions.  Trend vs baseline is often the fastest clarifier.
opts: Avoid reporting limitations to maintain confidence
Optimize acquisition/alignment, reconcile discordant parameters, explicitly state limitations, and use adjunct testing when echo remains indeterminate
Defer all decisions until symptoms resolve
Pick the single most severe number and report it as definitive
raw:
261. ACS2-0261 — Clinical Integration | Managing discordance and uncertainty
A symptomatic patient has borderline or discordant echo findings that could change management. Which next step
is most appropriate to reduce diagnostic uncertainty while remaining guideline-aligned?

A. Avoid reporting limitations to maintain confidence

B. Optimize acquisition/alignment, reconcile discordant parameters, explicitly state limitations, and use adjunct
testing when echo remains indeterminate

C. Defer all decisions until symptoms resolve

D. Pick the single most severe number and report it as definitive
Correct: B
Rationale: ACS-level reporting integrates multiple parameters, improves data quality, and escalates appropriately
when uncertainty persists.
Pearls: Good reports guide next actions.  Trend vs baseline is often the fastest clarifier.

title: Congenital Heart Disease | Shunt quantification (Qp/Qs)
stem:
Shunt quantification:
LVOT diameter 1.9 cm, LVOT VTI 16.7 cm.
RVOT diameter 2.3 cm, RVOT VTI 18.5 cm.
Assuming no significant regurgitation, what is Qp/Qs?

Rationale: Qp/Qs = (CSA_RVOT×VTI_RVOT)/(CSA_LVOT×VTI_LVOT) with CSA = π(d/2)². Calculated ≈ 1.62.
Pearls: Diameter is squared: small errors cause large Qp/Qs errors.  Confirm with chamber remodeling and color
flow.
raw:

D. Qp/Qs ≈ 1.91
Correct: D
Rationale: Qp/Qs = (CSA_RVOT×VTI_RVOT)/(CSA_LVOT×VTI_LVOT) with CSA = π(d/2)². Calculated ≈ 1.91.
Pearls: Diameter is squared: small errors cause large Qp/Qs errors.  Confirm with chamber remodeling and color
flow.

title: Congenital Heart Disease | Shunt quantification (Qp/Qs)
stem:
Shunt quantification:
LVOT diameter 2.0 cm, LVOT VTI 18.1 cm.
RVOT diameter 2.7 cm, RVOT VTI 22.3 cm.
Assuming no significant regurgitation, what is Qp/Qs?

Rationale: Qp/Qs = (CSA_RVOT×VTI_RVOT)/(CSA_LVOT×VTI_LVOT) with CSA = π(d/2)². Calculated ≈ 2.25.
Pearls: Diameter is squared: small errors cause large Qp/Qs errors.  Confirm with chamber remodeling and color
flow.
raw:
290. ACS2-0290 — Congenital Heart Disease | Shunt quantification (Qp/Qs)
Shunt quantification:
LVOT diameter 2.0 cm, LVOT VTI 18.1 cm.
RVOT diameter 2.7 cm, RVOT VTI 22.3 cm.
Assuming no significant regurgitation, what is Qp/Qs?

A. Qp/Qs ≈ 1.48

B. Qp/Qs ≈ 2.25

C. Qp/Qs ≈ 1.66

D. Qp/Qs ≈ 0.45
Correct: B
Rationale: Qp/Qs = (CSA_RVOT×VTI_RVOT)/(CSA_LVOT×VTI_LVOT) with CSA = π(d/2)². Calculated ≈ 2.25.
Pearls: Diameter is squared: small errors cause large Qp/Qs errors.  Confirm with chamber remodeling and color
flow.

title: Quality Improvement & Education | CQI process design
stem:
Your echo lab identifies the following issue:
Interobserver variability in LVOT diameter is high, driving inconsistent AVA reporting.
Which CQI intervention is most appropriate?

Rationale: CQI works best when metric-driven: baseline measurement, targeted intervention, and re-measurement
with feedback loops.
Pearls: If you can’t measure it, you can’t improve it.  Most 'people problems' are process problems.
opts: Ignore variability; clinical correlation makes precision unnecessary
Discipline individuals without defining a measurable process problem
Define a measurable metric, standardize protocol, retrain with audit-and-feedback, then re-measure (PDSA cycle)
Replace all quantitative measures with qualitative impressions only
raw:
